did.head: Collection Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: Wilton History Room, Wilton Historical Society

did.abstract: The Wilton Historical Society Map Collection contains maps and atlases of Wilton and Fairfield County, Connecticut, in addition to local blueprints, plans, charts, and lists of cartographical interest. The collection as a whole provides snapshots of Wilton since the 1700s, mapping Wilton businesses, homes, residents, and place names, showing developments in transportation, environment, and economy, and reflecting continuity and change in local cultures. The oldest dated items are photocopies, tracings, or drawings of originals; the earliest originals are from the mid- to late 1700s. The latest additions are from the end of the twentieth century.

userestrict.head: Publication Rights
userestrict.p: For copyright status, please contact the Wilton History Room, Wilton Historical Society.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Title or description], [folder, box, and/or item number(s)], Wilton Historical Society Maps Collection, Wilton History Room, Wilton Historical Society, Wilton Library, Wilton, Connecticut.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The bulk of the Wilton Historical Society Map Collection was compiled by the Wilton Historical Society, with select items donated by individuals and families.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: The Wilton Historical Society, founded in 1938, collected maps and related items of cartographical interest pertaining to Wilton, Fairfield County, and those portions of New York bordering Wilton. Additions have been made by Carol Russell, Wilton Historical Society Archivist and Wilton Town Historian. The majority of the material included in the collection was created by land surveyors and professional cartographers, with a few items independently produced by local Wiltonians. Local and state governments commissioned the bulk of items in the collection. Some materials were commissioned or amended by local chapters of national organizations, such as the League of Women Voters. A number of items in the collection have been annotated by Wilton historian G. Evans Hubbard.

The Wilton History Room is a unique collaboration between the Wilton Historical Society (WHS) and the Wilton Library Association (WLA). Compiled beginning in 1938, the archival collections of the Wilton Historical Society had been stored in the 18th century Fitch House. In 1980, the officers and trustees of the WHS, in conversation with the director and board members of the WLA, determined that a climate controlled space, improved organization, and better public accessibility were necessary; and so in January 1984 they established a home for the collection in the Wilton Library. Organization of the collections was supported by the Cudlipp Memorial Fund and undertaken by Carol Russell. The Wilton Historical Society has retained its ownership, while the Wilton Library maintains the collections, and provides access and assistance to patrons.

The Wilton History Room is one of the most complete, organized, and well-staffed historical research facilities, for a town of our size, in Fairfield County. It is supported by the WHS, the WLA, The Russell Fund, The History Room Fund, local non-profit organizations, individual donors, and community volunteers.

Today, the original archival collections of the WHS take up half of the Wilton History Room. Another quarter are library items. The collected papers of local organizations comprise the remainder: Cannon Grange, Children's Theater, Daughters of the American Revolution, Hurlbutt Street School House Association, Kiwanis Club, League of Women Voters, Rotary Club, Town Association, Weir Farm Stewardship Committee, Wilton Garden Club, Wilton Land Conservation Trust, Wilton Library, Wilton Playshop, Wilton Woman's Club, and more.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The Wilton Historical Society Map Collection provides snapshots of Wilton and its environs beginning in the early 1700s. There is a special emphasis throughout on property boundaries and borders with adjacent communities, roads and infrastructure, the locations of homes and names of residents, government and elections, school districts, places of business and industry, and the minutiae of local names and landmarks both permanent (such as Split Rock) and ephemeral (including chestnut stumps and stone piles). Major historical events, in contrast, are less well represented. The collection nevertheless contains important examples, notably a map of General Tryon's Raid during the Revolutionary War and another showing important sites associated with African American history and the Underground Railroad's passage through the area.

Traced or photocopied land surveys in the collection map properties belonging to early Wilton families in the first half of the 1700s, including the Baldwin, Belden, Betts, Birchard, Buckingham, Comstock, Hickcox, Stuart, Keeler, Kellogg, Ketchum, Lambert, Marvin, Olmsted, Platt, Resseguies, St. John, and Whitney families.

Original maps and traced or photocopied land surveys of Wilton neighborhoods in the collection include Belden Hill, Cave Woods, Keeler's Ridge, Kent, Ketchum Bogs, Lambert Corners, Quarry Head, Split Rock, Wilton Center, and many others.
Adjacent communities represented in the collection include Georgetown (Redding), New Canaan, Norwalk, Ridgefield, and Salem, New York.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arrangement of the collection is by the materials' physical properties, and by their availability for purchase. Individual non-salable items are stored as appropriate in tubes, map drawers, or on shelves. Map copies available for purchase are stored separately in two dedicated map drawers.

controlaccess.head: Indexing Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the library's online public access catalog.
controlaccess.subject: American Revolutionary War, 1775-1783.
City planning.
Historic buildings.
Ridgefield, Battle of, Ridgefield, Conn., 1777.
Homes.
Real property--Connecticut--Fairfield County--Maps.
Road maps.
Transportation--Maps.
School districts.
Neighborhoods.
Underground Railroad.
Zoning--Connecticut--Wilton (Town)--Maps.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Collections
relatedmaterial.p: Researchers interested in the history, locations, and boundaries of Wilton family properties and homes should also search for content organized by family names and historical locations of residence in the Wilton History Room's other collections, particularly Manuscripts and Neighborhoods. Property histories of select Wilton families and individuals are also narrated in Robert Russell's Wilton, Connecticut: Three Centuries of People, Places, and Progress. Finally, the Card File is helpful in locating specific family names mentioned in the early division of Wilton lands and the Norwalk Land Records.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Select additional maps are housed at the Wilton Historical Society Museum. Originals of pre-1802 land surveys, part of the Norwalk Land Records, are in the collections of the Norwalk Historical Society in the Norwalk History Room, Norwalk Public Library.
